SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Sarah J. McNeil,
Address: Box 37, Creelman, Sask.
Birthplace: The Ridge, Ontario)

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? S.W. 6-10-9 W2
Where had you been living before that? The Ridge, Hastings Co., Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 2
How far was it to your nearest store? 4 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Dried fruit, lard, sugar, corn syrup, beans, corn.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Five Roses
In what quantities did you buy it? 1 cwt. at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.75
How much did you use graham flour? Only for muffins
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? .......... What year? ......
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? .............
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? For Johnny cake Whole Wheat? Farina? ...........
Other? Grits
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it?

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) Spring of 1906 a hole beside slough then a well.

How far was this water from your home? Close by. Well of a mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Pail.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

A cistern (cement) in basement for soft water was built in 1916. This proved a great blessing in the drought of the 30's when neighbors hauled soft water for six miles.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

More parchment and waxed papers made cardboard containers are now used. The food was sold in bulk in the early days. One supplied their own containers, a string jug for vinegar and a qt. scale for molasses as a rule.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1906 Breakfast for myself and my brother
Homemade bacon, eggs, toast, dried fruit stewed tea.

Dinner: Fried pork, potatoes, corn, peas, rice or tapioca pudding, bread, butter, tea.

Supper: Boiled eggs, fried potatoes, salad, fruit cake, warm tea biscuits, tea.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? _______1914______ Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Roast turkey, cranberry sauce, mashed potatoes, peas, dressing, gravy, plum pudding, mince pie, tea, orange candy coins.

My brothers Theo. Henderson, his wife and baby daughter Beth, ages 35, 27 and baby Archie.

Also Grandma Fox, Mrs. Eleanor Fox, Mr. Henderson's mother.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

The shortage of domestic help has really been the cause of housewives having to buy more prepared foods, especially bought bread, prepared pie crust mix, cake mix etc. One pair of hands can only do so much.
